Mining giant rio tinto has lowered its minimum acceptances target slightly in a last ditch effort to takeover south africa's riversdale mining.
Rio's offer of 16.50 australian dollars ($16.42; â£10.14) is now conditional on 47% of shareholders accepting it by 6 april.
Previously its minimum target was 50%.
The move came after talks on the a$3.9bn offer between rio and riversdale major shareholder, brazil's csn.
If it fails to reach the new threshold, rio tinto will pay riversdale shareholders only a$16 a share.
So far only 41% have said yes.
The other key shareholder in riversdale is tata steel of india, which recently increased its stake to 27% and also has a director on the company's board.
Csn, brazil's largest steelmaker, has also increased its riversdale stake to 19.9%.
summary: Rio Tinto has lowered its minimum acceptances target to take over South Africa's Riversdale Mining. The offer of 16.50 Australian dollars ($16.42; Â£10.14) is now conditional on 47% of shareholders accepting it by 6 April, down from the previous target of 50%. So far, only 41% of shareholders have said yes. The other key shareholders in Riversdale are Tata Steel of India and CSN, Brazil's largest steelmaker, which recently increased its stake to 19.9%.

title: REDDIT-12:mistral7b-ul2
source:
This was about a week or two ago but i still think i should share this with you guys.
I was at football practice.
It was the first day of spring practice and i was practicing for qb (quarterbacks throw the ball for people who don't keep up with sports).
I practiced the whole day, got dehydrated and ended up almost passing out.
I asked a coach to go get water but he told me to continue to do the rest of the sprints.
Anyways, it became the end of the day.
It was time for me to practice with the whole offense.
I got in the huddle, called "flex right 2" and the just said "break?
".
For people who don't know, that's not how you do a huddle, this is how you do a huddle: 1) make sure your center is looking at you; make sure your huddle is worth something 2) make sure all eyes are on you 3) say the play twice on both sides of the huddle 4) say "ready, break" i figured it out and i got in position.
I said, "ready go" and the center snapped me the ball.
Now listen, i have no idea what i just called in the huddle.
I just copied exactly what coach told me to say but i didn't know what "flex right 2" was.
So, i got the snap, i looked to my right, and threw the ball to the right outside wide receiver.
I was so proud of myself.
"i threw an accurate pass to the wr and coach will be proud!!"
I thought.
Then the offensive line gets up and says, "didn't he say two?"
I thought, "yeah i said two?"
So i get back in the huddle, and i asked coach, "did i do something wrong?"
"hell yeah!"
He yelled, "you threw on a run play!"
Instantly, i thought i was going to get kicked off the team.
The only thing i could do was say, "i'm so sorry," about 30 times.
I ended up getting yelled at, told if i do that again, i was being moved to another position, and i got laughed at and made fun of for the rest of the week and still even today by other players and friends.
So i quit.
I talked to my coach about it and since he knows i want to play guitar and film more, he offered a shot to go back during the fall and actually film the games!
Then he said if i want to make a career out of it, he could call his good friend from south carolina to possibly get me scholarship money to go down there and film the games.
summary: The document describes the author's experience at a football practice where they practiced for QB and became dehydrated. The author asked for water, but a coach instructed them to continue practicing. During a game, the author called a huddle incorrectly and accidentally threw the ball on a run play, leading to being yelled at and laughed at by other players and friends. The author quit the team and talked to their coach about it. The coach offered the author a chance to go back during the fall to film the games and potentially receive scholarship money to go down to South Carolina to film games.

title: REDDIT-79:gpt4-ul2
source:
This technically happened today, but started late last night.
So i was very determined to finish writing my annotated bibliography for ap language before it was due.
I finished it at just after midnight after working on it for a few hours.
As i was getting ready for bed, i saw my phone on my bedside table and forgot it was even there.
I had some missed texts and emails, but nothing too important.
I checked the battery life, and it was fully charged.
I thought to myself that i'd leave it on the other side of the room so when the alarm goes off, i have to get up and turn it off.
My alarm goes off at 6:30 in the morning.
This is a very vulnerable time for me, especially after hours of writing.
So right on cue, the alarm goes off, i get up, and i go to turn it off.
The problem with that was i couldn't find my phone.
I was frantically searching for it in my groggy state, moving papers around, moving folders around, nothing.
I ran into my mom's room and told her to call my phone because i couldn't find it.
She hears my alarm and looks at me like i'm stupid.
I go back in my room and shut off the alarm that was right on the edge of my desk and i go back to sleep.
Then i woke up late and ran out to get to school.
summary: The author was determined to finish their AP Language annotated bibliography before the due date. They completed this just after midnight and, after noticing their forgotten phone, decided to put it on the other side of the room; their logic being that they would have to physically get up to turn off the 6:30am alarm. However, when the alarm went off, they couldn't find their phone due to their groggy state. After a frantic but unsuccessful search, they woke their mom for help, only to find the phone blaring the alarm on the edge of their desk. The author then went back to sleep, subsequently waking up late and rushing to school.

title: XSUM-36628767:mistral7b-ul2
source:
Tributes were paid to service personnel at hundreds of events around the uk on armed forces day.
Earlier prime minister david cameron attended the main celebration at cleethorpes in north east lincolnshire.
It featured an aerobatic display by the red arrows, a battle of britain memorial flight and parachute display by the royal navy, army and raf.
On monday, a flag-raising ceremony was held at city hall, in london, to mark this year's events.
Follow live updates of armed forces day events alex baxter, armed forces champion for north east lincolnshire, said: "hosting armed forces day will give our residents and others in the region an unparalleled opportunity to show their support and appreciation for serving and former armed forces personnel."
The main celebration also included a display of military vehicles, including the sandown-class mine countermeasures vessel hms blyth, the as90 artillery tank and the warrior and terrier armoured vehicles.
North east lincolnshire council leader ray oxby said: "our local armed forces day has previously attracted more than 60,000 people into the area for the weekend to recognise our past and serving military personnel, and i've no doubt that figure will be dwarfed by hosting the national day."
summary: Armed Forces Day was celebrated in the UK with hundreds of events, including a main celebration at Cleethorpes in North East Lincolnshire. The event featured an aerobatic display by the Red Arrows, a Battle of Britain Memorial Flight, and a parachute display by the Royal Navy, Army, and RAF. A flag-raising ceremony was also held at City Hall in London to mark the occasion. The main celebration included a display of military vehicles and attracted more than 60,000 people. Alex Baxter, the armed forces champion for North East Lincolnshire, stated that hosting Armed Forces Day would give the community an opportunity to show their support and appreciation for serving and former military personnel.

title: XSUM-39219188:llama7b-ul2
source:
Amputee football is played all over the world but it is in its infancy in scotland, where organisers are trying to form a new league.
"it gives me a lot of confidence and a lot of good friends," says one of the players on a five-a-side football pitch in the north of glasgow.
He's moving around nimbly on crutches, putting everything into the training and drills.
There are shouts for the ball, plenty of laughter but lots of hard work.
After all some of the players here have their next competitive game in just over a week.
Many of them do play on crutches, others with prosthetic limbs.
The sport of amputee football has been going for many years south of the border and now a charity is now trying to form a scotland-wide league.
It is holding the first amputee football scottish cup in edinburgh next month.
This team i am watching is linked to partick thistle.
"i wish, looking back, i hadn't let it stop me," says brian murray, who lost his leg to cancer at the age of 10.
He says that, although as a youngster he did play on crutches with his pals, when he went to secondary school he lost confidence and began wearing his prosthetic leg all the time.
His introduction to amputee football was in england, regularly travelling to everton to get a game.
It is rough at times - he broke his collarbone last year, but did not let that put him off.
He describes the sport now being in scotland as "brilliant".
"that's what i want to give to youngsters," he says.
"don't let anyone stop you, just go for it."
He adds that if he is still playing at the age of 47, then "it doesn't matter what age you are".
Amputee football is played all over the world.
In turkey, for instance, there is a professional league, aired on television with 600 players.
Scotland is hoping to play some friendlies against other european countries later in the year.
"amputee football is just about getting people out and playing football," says ashley reid of the amputee football association scotland (afas).
"the limb difference, the amputation is not relevant at all when people are here training.
It's just about playing football."
She says she saw a clear demand for the sport in scotland.
The task now is to try to spread out across the country.
In among the men on the pitch is one woman.
In fact, she is the only woman playing in the amputee football league in the uk.
"all amputees are used to being the odd one out in the crowd," rebecca sellar explains.
"so coming into this as the only woman, you get on with it and over it."
She would like to get more women involved.
Rebecca says that since she started she has been welcomed into the game and on a personal level has gained fitness as well as the enjoyment of taking part in a team sport.
She says: "our numbers are growing and the more word we can get out there to encourage people to get involved the better we can have it as a sport for scotland."
summary: Amputee football is a sport played by people with physical disabilities, including those with limb loss or limb difference. In Scotland, there is an effort to form a new league, with the first Scottish Amputee Football Cup being held in Edinburgh next month. The sport is popular in other countries, including Turkey, where there is a professional league, and Scotland hopes to play friendlies against other European countries later in the year. The Amputee Football Association Scotland (AFAS) is leading the effort to promote the sport in Scotland, with the goal of spreading it across the country.

spans.text: with physical disabilities, including those with limb loss or limb difference

title: XSUM-28345611:mistral7b-ul2
source:
When you think of a laboratory you wouldn't usually think of cheering crowds or actors in costumes.
You might not associate academic analysis with raucous outdoor performances or atmospheric indoor shows under candlelight.
But shakespeare's globe on london's bankside is a kind of living laboratory, with its own team of in-house scholars, researchers and academic advisers.
Everything from the physical design of the theatre through to the individual performances is informed by the insights and research work of academics the globe's site beside the river thames now has two theatres, with the opening of an indoor jacobean theatre alongside the existing thatch-roofed, open-air playhouse.
Building this much smaller, enclosed theatre, called the sam wanamaker playhouse, was an academic challenge in itself.
Farah karim-cooper, one of the globe's resident scholars, says that it's not a replica of a specific playhouse of the era, but a building assembled from different pieces of architectural evidence and contemporary sources.
The design, a wooden candle-lit chamber, with some of the audience practically on stage, is the result of "informed, rigorous speculation, based on all the available evidence".
But this doesn't mean an obsessive interest in re-creating "authenticity", says dr karim-cooper.
The buildings, like the performances, are about a living, breathing engagement with modern audiences.
"we're not interested in re-enactment," she says.
But she considers the theatre an experiment in seeing how things work in practice.
Like how do you move a play from the operatic scale of outdoor theatre to the close-up intimacy of the indoor theatre?
It was something that happened regularly in shakespeare's day, taking plays from the outdoor globe to an indoor playhouse such as the blackfriars, built in the atmospheric ruins of a monastery on the other side of the river thames.
It must have been like a rock band switching from a festival stage to a nightclub.
The globe was playing in daylight to open-air crowds, while the indoor theatre was a smaller, much wealthier audience, watching close-up in candlelight.
The globe team researched different types of candles, with beeswax chosen over tallow for the warmth of the light.
And in terms of lighting effects, the indoor theatre has pulley-operated candelabra - or else the actors themselves carry candles.
Light and darkness were almost characters in their own right in plays of this pre-electric era.
"darkness was a terrifying presence," says dr karim-cooper.
"darkness was palpable, something that people seemed to be able to touch, it was so thick.
It was very much associated with all the horrors of the imagination, the devil, demons, witchcraft -  that dark, dark world they felt was out there."
She says that if elizabethans or jacobeans travelled in time to modern london "their retinas would burn if they saw our levels of light".
Another big difference is that shakespeare's audiences would have been in the same lighting level as the actors on stage.
The modern experience of an audience sitting in the dark while the stage is illuminated - a convention carried into the cinema - would have been completely unknown.
In the indoor theatres, audiences were paying high prices to see and be seen.
The really big spenders could sit in seats at the side of the stage, where they expected to be as much part of the spectacle as the actors.
And one of the most distinctive features of plays at the reconstructed globe is that it's impossible not to watch the audience as much as the play.
"it was a very social occasion," says dr karim-cooper, describing the shakespearean-era theatre as a long day out, with little precise time-keeping and much comment on who was in the crowd and the finery of what they were wearing.
"contemporary accounts are more about the audience and who was there and what happened - more than the actual play," she says.
Putting the actors and audience in clear view of one another changes how plays would have been performed.
For instance, the great soliloquies in the tragedies become a conversation with the audience, says dr karim-cooper.
Modern audiences, in a darkened auditorium, might expect these classic speeches to be a form of introspective, interior monologue.
When the audience and actors are looking into each other's eyes, it becomes a different moment.
There are other big changes between a modern and shakespearean theatre visit.
It would have smelled very different, says dr karim-cooper.
There would have been a heady mix of the perfumes that were highly prized, alongside the earthy scent of thousands of people crammed in together.
Another sensory difference would have been the "soundscape", she says.
It would have been a much softer sound, as elizabethan london didn't have engines or loud machinery or amplified music.
"in terms of how loud things can get, they had no idea," she says.
"there are accounts of people being freaked out by the audience clapping in a playhouse, the sound was so overwhelming.
They never heard a plane taking off."
The language would have sounded unusual too.
The accent of the time would have meant words such as "move" and "love" would have sounded much closer to rhyming.
And the globe has been presenting readings of plays with the original pronunciation.
The role of the theatre's research team isn't to be trainspotters in historical accuracy but to provide practical advice for actors and directors.
"there is nothing worse than an academic who has never been on a stage, saying this is what you should do.
It wouldn't work," says dr karim-cooper.
Instead they talk to the performers about the plays and can research any detailed questions.
They pride themselves on a quick turnaround, going to the original sources and delivering an authoritative report within a few days.
"we want to get beyond wikipedia," she says.
She is co-editor of moving shakespeare indoors, a collection of essays on indoor jacobean theatres, and education is a key part of the globe's work.
There is a postgraduate degree course in shakespeare studies with king's college, london.
There are outreach projects with local schools and training events for teachers.
Every year there is a landmark schools production, the playing shakespeare series, with thousands of free tickets for london pupils.
It's been a huge success, with many  coming to see shakespeare plays who have never been inside a theatre before.
Dr karim-cooper says they want to extend the idea of the theatre as a laboratory.
"we want to become a research hub.
We want students to be here."
The "unique blend" will be the dramatic experimentation alongside the "literary rigour".
"we don't separate the practical from the academic."
summary: The Shakespeare's Globe Theatre in London is a unique combination of academia and theatre, with a team of scholars, researchers, and academic advisors informing every aspect of the theatre's operation. The site now includes two theatres, the open-air Globe and the indoor Sam Wanamaker Playhouse, which was built with an informed, rigorous speculation based on all available evidence. The indoor theatre features lighting effects such as pulley-operated candelabras or actors carrying candles. Shakespearean audiences would have been in the same lighting level as the actors, and the modern experience of an audience sitting in the dark while the stage is illuminated is completely unknown.

Welsh housing associations directly contributed more than £1bn to the economy in 2014/15, an independent report has said.
The welsh economy research report showed 79% of direct spend was retained in wales, and associations built nearly 2,000 affordable homes.
This was an increase of 4% on the previous year.
The annual report, commissioned by community housing cymru, looked at the impact of social housing in wales.
£1.1bn contributed to the economy in 2014/15 £872m of that was retained in wales 1,923 new homes built in 2014/15 £301m on repairs/maintenance in 2014/15 £532m on regeneration in 2014/15
summary: According to an independent report, Welsh housing associations contributed over £1 billion to the economy in 2014/15. Of this amount, 79% was retained in Wales, and associations built nearly 2,000 affordable homes, an increase of 4% from the previous year. The report was commissioned by Community Housing Cymru and looked at the impact of social housing in Wales.

title: REDDIT-13:mistral7b-ul2
source:
So unlike the majority of posts i see here this actually happened today (woah, what!?)
And it left me feeling like i had just ruined the childhood of my cousin.
  so, this fu happened at a casual family breakfast where we had our extended family over.
Anyway, my father asks my uncle, his brother, what he had planned over the easter break and of course as soon as someone mentions easter, the younger kids start getting all excited over the fact that easter is around the corner and about how they're going to "get all the easter eggs and chocolate, even yours, you don't need it you're fat, the easter bunny won't visit you because you don't need them!"
And so on.
Anyway, i find it humorous for about 10 minutes (i should probably mention that i'm not a large fan of young children, i get easily frustrated after too much obnoxiousness, kids man, they can't help it) so i end up going upstairs to my room, unfortunately my cousin ended up following me and continued the tirade of insults, purely innocent and i wasn't the least bit offended by what he was saying, i was laughing along with him but here was where i fucked up.
I ended up saying something along the lines of 'okay that's enough now, how do you know the easter bunny is even real?'
As a joke and i made it clear as soon as i said it that i was just kidding and that if he acts up the easter bunny won't come.
But fuck me man, i'd already done it.
  he then says to me "but if you haven't seen him, then he can't be real....", completely missing the point mind you but his personality is very stubborn and isn't easily swayed.
Once he gets something in his head, it's almost impossible to convince him otherwise.
I didn't know what to say cause i already know what this kid is like and i had just gone and given my aunt and uncle a very difficult task of trying to convince him that there is, in fact, an easter bunny.
He was crying when he came to this conclusion and ran downstairs to his parents telling them his discovery, to which they gave me the biggest death stare i had ever gotten.
To my dismay, he didn't stop there, the next sentence left me feeling like an absolute cunt.
He says "but if there is no easter bunny then santa clause, the tooth fairy and jesus can't be real either!"
(not going to lie, it took everything i had in me not to laugh when he mentioned jesus).
Anyway, the result is that my parents hate me, my aunt and uncle despise me and i doubt anyone in my family will ever speak to me again, guess it's time to revert back to my reclusive existence because family interaction is now a thing of the past.
summary: The document describes an unfortunate incident at a family gathering where the author made a joke about the Easter Bunny, which offended their cousin and caused the family to turn against them. The cousin's reaction was so extreme that the author's parents now hate them, and they doubt that anyone in the family will ever speak to them again.

title: REDDIT-14:llama7b-ul2
source:
I have a classmate who is really interested in guns, knives, explosives etc., we'll call him a. many weeks back, i took back some magnesium powder from the school lab for campfire effects.
A saw me placing it inside my locker, and offered to trade a spoonful of magnesium for a handmade firecracker explosive.
I agreed, as it sounded pretty awesome.
It looked like a cherry bomb but it was really small.
He told me that all i had to do was to light up the fuse and wait for it to explode.
Today i attempted to detonate it in class.
That was the first mistake because its an enclosed classroom.
Everyone else was at other lessons so it was empty.
Moving the tables to the side, i created a space where it could "safely detonate".
Lighting it, i ran to the back of class and took cover.
The fuse was a sparkler and it burnt all the way till the flash powder, but nothing happened.
I took out the fuse and realized that the portion of it inside the flash powder had already disintegrated.
This is the stupid part.
I didn't know what i was thinking.
Maybe i thought it was a dud or something.
I took my lighter and lit the rest of it.
My left hand (thumb, index and middle finger) was holding it when it exploded.
It was really loud and made me go partially deaf for the next 5 minutes.
My fingertips are heavily bruised and there is a bit of internal bleeding under my middle fingernail.
Right now i'm suffering from tinnitus in my left ear as i type with only my right hand.
My left hand is in a sock with ointment on it.
My only fear of this is that my hearing may be damaged and this could result in me not being able to go for a private pilot license course i plan to take up at the end of the year.
If anyone has shot guns without earplugs before, you may know what i'm going through now.
Do advise.
I didn't dare to tell my parents the truth, so i told them i smashed my fingers in the doorway.
For the hearing issue, i'm not sure how i'm gonna explain that.
P.s i think this is karma, because i drew a huge realistic penis on my friend's physics workbook yesterday.
Doesn't help that the 3 fingers injured form fleming's left hand rule.
Update: fingers and hearing pretty much back to normal, now i've paid the price of stupidity.
Now i think through everything many times before making a decision to avoid future fus.
Have a nice day.
summary: A student wrote in about an incident where they tried to make a homemade explosive device in school, but it didn't work as planned and caused injuries to their fingers. The student is now experiencing hearing loss and is concerned about the potential long-term effects on their ability to pursue a private pilot license. They reflect on their actions as a lesson learned and vow to think through decisions more carefully in the future.

title: XSUM-37820092:mistral7b-ul2
source:
Shanghai is trialling a unisex public toilet block to lower the time women have to spend waiting in queues, chinese media have reported.
The toilet, in a busy park in pudong new area, will have 10 unisex stalls, plus some urinals and a stall for disabled people.
The opening on 19 november will coincide with world toilet day.
Unisex facilities will spare officials having to decide how to share out male and female stalls, say reports.
"it is an apparent problem that women have to wait in lines for toilets," fu liping, an official involved in the project, was quoted as saying, by the xinhua news agency.
The stalls will be more spacious than regular ones.
To guarantee safety and privacy, there will be attendants and higher partitions between stalls.
But there are no plans yet to build more unisex toilets, as authorities are unsure whether citizens will embrace the idea.
Their caution seem to be well-grounded, as people online have been less than enthusiastic about the unisex lavatory.
"i don't really support the idea.
After all, men and female are different," said weibo user zhu zhu xia.
Another weibo user said: "the problem will be solved if they build double female toilets."
summary: Shanghai is trialting a unisex public toilet block to decrease the time women have to wait in queues. The toilet, located in a park in Pudong New Area, will have 10 unisex stalls, urinals, and a stall for disabled people. The opening on 19 November coincides with World Toilet Day. Unisex facilities will spare officials from having to decide how to share out male and female stalls. However, there are no plans yet to build more unisex toilets as authorities are unsure whether citizens will embrace the idea.

title: REDDIT-37:falcon7b-ul2
source:
Context: i've recently come down with a pretty nasty ear infection, that just seems to get worse.
On the first day, my inner ear felt congested, and flared up in pain when i bit down on anything.
Obviously, i decide to head to a clinic, and was promptly diagnosed with an inner ear infection.
On the second day, i felt lightheaded and dizzy, but decided to push on through.
However, by the third day, i was starting to feel queasy, and heavily feverish.
I checked my temp with an oral thermometer, and, just as i suspected, i was running a low fever.
Now, here's where the tifu starts.
A couple weeks back, i made plans with a friend to go see justice league.
We were both pretty hyped up, because we're pretty big fans of the characters.
Even though i was feeling pretty shitty, i decided to go through with our  plans, and go anyways.
I had started to feel a little better by the time noon rolled around, so i thought i could keep it together until i got back home.
Boy, was i wrong.
When we got to the theater, my fever had slowly started to return, along with a stomach ache.
It started out pretty mild, but slowly progressed.
By the midway point, i was barely keeping it together.
Around the setup to the climax, i could feel my throat burning, and my stomach rumbling like a geyser, preparing to erupt.
And erupt it did... as i was starting to get ready to make a break for the bathroom, the inevitable time bomb that was my gut finally exploded.
Thanks to the advice i'd gotten about staying hydrated, the nearly-endless stream of vomit that shot out of my mouth was extra liquidy, leading to an ever growing puddle of puke, swelling up around my shoes.
Quickly, the soupy stream of spew made it's way down the isle, alerting everyone that hadn't already noticed the atrocity i had just committed before them.
Soon came an endless torrent of remarks, such as "geez, why's it all wet here?
", "who just spilled their drink?"
"why is my shoe so moist?"
And many more.
Eventually, the ushers had become aware of the mess i had  just jettisoned from my throat, and started evacuating the theater.
I couldn't make eye contact with my friend, as i rushed back to my car to speed home.
summary: feeling a little under the weather, a friend and he decided to go see a movie. as time passed and the symptoms worsed, they decided to go anyways. the friend had started feeling better but his stomach ache worsened. his fever slowly returned, along with a stomach ache. the severity worsened and he began to vomit. in a crowded theater, his stomach fluid sprayed onto the floor, creating a puddle. several people in the audience turned to see who the mess was coming from, leading to him feeling humiliated. the rest of the day went on, with him barely keeping it together, before finally returning home.

spans.text: the friend had started feeling better
as time passed and the symptoms worsed, they decided to go anyways

title: REDDIT-78:gpt4-ul2
source:
Some background information first; i'm in high school so the whole dating thing is kind of new to me.
I've known her for a while but i have just recently started talking to her a good amount the last year.
So the obligatory it didn't happen today, but last october.
So there was this girl i liked.
Let's call her sarah.
So some of my friends have a hunch that i liked her, but i never really admitted it.
I had been debating asking her but i decided against it because i figured it wouldn't end well.
But at home coming, i finally gave in and went for it.
I went up and asked her if she'd want to go see the new (at the time) divergent movie with me on friday.
She was so shocked she had no idea what to say.
She responded to me asking her out with "well i guess i can't say no".
Not a good sign, but at that point i don't care.
My friends are all happy for me and i have a good rest of home coming.
Fast forward to thursday morning, in science class.
The only class i have with her.
She keeps bringing up how she feels like she's going to get sick.
I'm thinking maybe she's just trying to get out of it.
Friday comes and she's not at school.
I tried texting her but no response.
(the next monday i learn she broke her phone) i'm pretty upset at this point.
One of my friends that's known for inviting himself to this sort of thing thinks it's a good idea to invite himself and a few friends.
So we get to the theatre and there i am.
Alone, with no idea where she is or what happened.
My friend who invited himself is having a good time with the people he invited while i sat there eating my candy wanting to leave already.
Now days we're friends and we laugh about it.
Never going to forget this first date.
summary: The author, in high school, recounts their first experience with dating. The author had feelings for a girl named Sarah and eventually mustered the courage to ask her out at a homecoming event. Although initially taken aback, Sarah agreed to go see a movie with the author. However, upon the day of the date, the author was stood up as Sarah did not respond to texts and was absent from school. The author later found out she had broken her phone. The author’s friend invited himself and other friends to the movie, which resulted in the author feeling alone and disappointed. Despite the event, the author and Sarah have maintained their friendship and can now laugh about the incident.

title: REDDIT-8:gpt4-ul2
source:
I'd like to preface this by saying i'm an iphone user.
I've been an iphone user for many years and have always enjoyed their devices.
That being said, i was a little bit disappointed by the specifications on their latest iteration of their iphone.
With the recent birth of my daughter, i decided that i wanted a phone with a higher resolution than what the iphone 6 could offer (8 megapixels).
At first i was tempted to go with the note edge or note 4 but realised that a phone with a smaller profile would suit me better.
Enter the sony xperia z3 compact, 20.7 megapixel camera and an amazing battery capacity (2,600 mah) to boot.
In terms of requirements, this phone ticked all the boxes and was even waterproof up to 1.5 meters for up to half an hour, what more could i ask for?
I quickly snapped up this phone along with all the accessories, screen protector, magnetic cable and a magnetic dock to avoid opening the case during charge in case i damaged the seals on the device which kept it waterproof.
I loved the device so much that i ended up buying another for my father and convinced my father-in-law to purchase one too!
Soon, i even replaced my ipad 2 with the z3 compact tablet.
Now fast forward three weeks, my wife and i decide to take our daughter to her first trip to the pool.
"perfect", i think to myself - my phone is waterproof up to 1.5 meters for up to 30 minutes.
So in my daughter goes, with me in tow with my shiny new z3 compact.
Now before i went in, i double, triple, quadruple checked that all the seals in my phone were closed.
Hell, if i bought all those magnetic chargers i sure as hell wasn't going to leave a gate open for water to get in.
The phone worked great, i took some pictures and felt like a hero as everyone marveled at my waterproof phone.
Not that i was in that deep mind you, less than a meter since my daughter couldn't swim and needed the support of my wife and i. mere minutes pass and i feel immense heat coming from my phone, i check it and the screen is black and unresponsive.
I exit the pool feeling discombobulated, wonder what was wrong with my phone.
I dry the device off and give it a close inspection, mist was building up in the camera lenses, i open the gates and droplets of water begin to  fall out... shit.
I'm red faced but that's alright, it's a mass-manufactured device, sometimes these things happen, i'm sure sony will take care of it.
So i gave sony a call and arrange for the device to be sent back to an authorised repairer in australia.
It's christmas so it will take a few days and luckily i still had my old iphone 5 handy.
Three weeks later i receive the phone back in the mail with a note saying that it had passed the pressure tests and warranty won't be honoured by sony.
I call sony to discuss how this is possible since the gates were closed and water had obviously entered the device, sony will no longer cover the device and have nothing further to comment since it supposedly passed the pressure tests.
I have no avenue to appeal or request a second opinion.
I fucked up by touting how good the product was and have been left high and dry by the company whose products i was spruiking.
During the period that my phone has been out of action, i've missed the opportunity to capture key moments such as my daughter's first steps.
Now even if i bought another device, i would be afraid to put it near water in the event that it gets waterlogged and pressure testing indicates otherwise.
**
summary: The document is a detailed account of a long-time iPhone user who decided to switch to Sony's Xperia Z3 compact, drawn by its higher-resolution camera and waterproof feature. However, after confidently putting its waterproof capability to the test during a family outing to the pool, the phone became non-responsive despite ensuring all seals were closed. The user sent the phone to an authorised repairer, only to receive it back unrepaired, with Sony stating it "passed the pressure tests" and therefore the warranty would not be honoured. This frustrating experience, combined with the missed opportunity to document significant family milestones, has left the user disappointed and wary of repeating the same mistake.

title: XSUM-35455958:llama70b-ul2
source:
Derry football manager damian barton has described the facial injury sustained by his player brendan rogers in last weekend's dr mckenna cup final as "horrific".
Media playback is not supported on this device rogers needed 14 stitches in his lip after a challenge by tyrone's tiernan mccann at the start of the game.
"i think brendan was quite shocked.
Some people were quite horrified," said the derry manager.
"i'll leave it to other people to make up their minds."
The slaughtneil man had the stitches inserted last sunday and barton expects rogers to be out of action for a couple of more weeks.
Rogers was named at midfield for the mckenna cup final and the match video suggested he may have been caught by mccann's right elbow immediately after challenging for the initial throw-in.
After the ball was thrown in, mccann came in from the side and the footage showed the tyrone man clattering into rogers although the red hand county player appeared to be focusing on the ball rather than the derry midfielder when the contact was made.
"brendan has been very quiet about it and we have been very quiet about it as well," said barton after derry's opening 3-13 to 1-10 division 2 football league victory over fermanagh at celtic park.
"it was quite an horrific incident.
I wouldn't like to expand on it to be quite frank.
Media playback is not supported on this device "it was an incident that thankfully you don't see very often."
Barton added that he "couldn't speak" after the game such was his upset about the incident.
"i think it affected the mood of all of us.
"it overshadowed for me what was a positive night for football.
"i think the amount of respect that was shown between derry and tyrone was very evident but it's one of those things i'll let people make up their own minds about."
In terms of sunday's opening league win, barton felt that his team had laboured badly in the first half before going on to clinch a nine-point victory over the erne county.
"we were very flat at the start of the game.
We turned over a serious amount of ball under no pressure.
"i was glad to see our first goal going in (before half-time) and i was very happy to see half-time because it gave us an opportunity to restructure and talk about what we felt we were going wrong.
"getting in the ball in early in the second half to our men inside worked nicely in the inclement conditions but we'll have to up our performances over the next couple of weeks."
summary: Derry football manager Damian Barton described the facial injury sustained by his player Brendan Rogers in a recent game as "horrific". Rogers needed 14 stitches after a challenge by a Tyrone player, and Barton expects him to be out of action for a couple more weeks. Barton declined to comment further on the incident, saying that he would let others make up their own minds about it. Derry won their opening league game against Fermanagh, but Barton felt that his team had labored in the first half before improving in the second half.

title: XSUM-30573259:gpt4-ul2
source:
A disc jockey has been jailed for eight months for stealing money from a children's cancer charity linked to the oscar knox appeal.
Gary neville, from cupar way, belfast, raised â£930 at a charity fundraising music night he organised last year.
He was prosecuted for failing to give the cash to the neuroblastoma children's cancer charity.
Oscar knox, a five-year-old boy from glengormley, county antrim, died from the rare and aggressive cancer in may.
The child's story captured the attention of the northern ireland public as each step of his cancer battle was followed on social networking sites.
Neville's solicitor told the court his 33-year-old client was "utterly ashamed" of his actions.
The lawyer said he had got into financial difficulty and was under threat of eviction from his home.
He added that neville had written a letter of apology to the the knox family.
Sentencing him to eight months in prison, the judge said it was absolutely shocking he would use circumstances such as a child's death for financial gain.
Neville, who is currently in prison for other offences, was told his term will run concurrently with his sentence.
The knox family set up the oscar knox appeal and still use the networking sites to raise awareness and funds for organisations helping children with neuroblastoma.
summary: A disc jockey named Gary Neville from Belfast has been given an eight month prison sentence for stealing funds from the Neuroblastoma Children's Cancer charity, intended for the Oscar Knox appeal. Neville raised £930 ($1220) during a charity music night he organised, but failed to pass the donations to the charity. Neville, already in prison for other offences, claimed to be in deep financial troubles and expressed remorse for his actions. The charity was set up by the family of Oscar Knox, a five-year-old who tragically succumbed to the rare form of cancer in May. The appeal continues to raise awareness and funds for children struggling with Neuroblastoma.

title: XSUM-34814828:geminipro-ul2
source:
Surely some of the first rules of wooing are: if you're going to do it, do it properly.
Don't insult the object of your desire with promises you both know you can't keep.
If you lack the cash for that magnificent bunch of fragrant roses, resist the temptation to brandish a fraying fake bouquet instead.
There has to be a better alternative, and you're unlikely to get a positive response.
And as for trying to bully or force someone into partnership with you - a little tip: it's unlikely to go down well.
In this respect, the eu makes a lousy suitor.
After reeling in panic and reacting in slow motion to the - to an extent predicted - dramatic surge this year in refugees and other migrants arriving, the eu is now trying a more comprehensive, strategic approach.
It includes an attempt to persuade (woo/push) the migrants' countries of origin, or the transit countries, to: migration to europe explained in graphics the eu also plans to send cash and other aid "over there", in the hope of dissuading more refugees and others from wanting to reach europe, risking their lives.
A rather similar formula worked for spain several years ago when it was the main eu arrival point for people smugglers' boats.
Bilateral deals with morocco and mauritania significantly reduced the arrival of "pateras", as spaniards nicknamed those boats.
But spain came under fire from aid organisations (ngos) at the time for trying to make african countries the "gatekeepers of europe".
The ngos also raised concerns about possible human rights abuses against would-be migrants blocked at the border.
They complained that the bilateral agreements, sorely lacking in transparency, smacked more of backroom deals.
Similar concerns are now being directed at the eu as a whole.
This week, the eu hosted a summit in malta with african nations, in the hope of coming to an "understanding" on slowing the flow of migrants to europe.
But, in addition to ngo concerns (such as the risk of groups linked to human rights abuses, like the eritrean security forces, siphoning off money allocated to stop migrants), african leaders widely dismissed eu offers of cash and other aid, as far too little to tackle the root causes of migration.
As flowers go, the extra aid package doesn't even make the gaudy plastic category.
The eu offered €3.6bn ($3.9bn; £2.5bn) to improve life in a number of african countries.
This in addition to the €20bn it already gives in aid to africa.
Somalia's distinctly unimpressed prime minister omar abdirashid ali sharmarke put it to the bbc that africa needed investment, not charity, to improve its economies.
The same as the us, the eu or anywhere else in the world, he said.
In fact, eu countries couldn't even muster the pledged extra cash.
It's a promise they seem unable or unwilling to keep.
The european commission says it will put in €1.8bn and wants the rest of the new fund made up by individual european nations.
So far they've coughed up less than €80m.
The eu was also unable to persuade/charm - some say bully - african countries into automatically receiving deported migrants back.
Instead, in the written summit conclusions, the eu was forced to emphasise "voluntary repatriations".
That prompted obvious questions about the bloc's declared aim of "speeding up the return" of economic migrants and other failed asylum seekers - a key part of its plan to tackle the migrant crisis.
In short: the summit was not a resounding success.
And a number of european newspapers were critical of the eu even trying to make a deal.
Germany's sueddeutsche zeitung says the eu's offer of money to reduce the refugee numbers from africa could open the eu to accusations of "showing its real values by co-operating with unjust regimes".
Similar objections are raised when it comes to eu attempts to strike a deal with turkey - now the main departure point for refugees and other migrants crossing to europe.
Eu leaders are planning a turkey summit before the end of the year, but - as german chancellor angela merkel has pointed out - "ankara holds the cards".
And diplomats worry that ankara will demand an extravagant bouquet in terms of money and political concessions - such as lifting visa restrictions, and accelerating turkey's eu membership bid - in exchange for help on migration.
And again, critics challenge the eu for courting turkey at all - a country with an imperious president and dismal human rights record.
There are also those who say the eu's focus is far too fixed on creating "fortress europe", on keeping people out and not on introducing legal ways for them to come to over.
Because come they will.
The european commission expects about three million refugees and other migrants to arrive in europe by 2017.
Clearly, whatever the eu does during this crisis, it will come under fire from some quarter or another.
All too often, it comes up against itself - a behemoth of 28 nations, struggling to work together.
Even the quota system - accepted (reluctantly) by most eu countries - to share out more equally the asylum seekers in europe is an unmitigated flop so far.
Agreed number of people to be relocated: 160,000.
People moved to date: 147.
Cross-border co-operation is disintegrating as barbed wire goes up and borders slam shut across europe: in slovenia, hungary, austria, sweden, norway… even germany is toughening border regulations.
In stark contrast to the warm welcome given to hundreds or thousands earlier this autumn, wolfgang schaeuble, germany's hugely popular finance minister, has begun to mutter darkly about a migrant "avalanche" engulfing his country.
There's little evidence of the eu - more of each country for itself.
That prompted the president of the european council, donald tusk, to warn that schengen, the eu agreement allowing passport-free travel across much of europe, risks collapse.
Yet it is one of the eu's proudest achievements.
You could argue schengen has already wilted and died.
summary: The European Union (EU) has been struggling to handle the recent surge of migrants and refugees arriving in Europe. In response, the EU has attempted to persuade the migrants' countries of origin, or the transit countries, to stem the flow of migrants. The EU has offered financial assistance and other aid to these countries, but these offers have been largely rejected as insufficient. The EU has also been criticized for its lack of transparency and accountability in its dealings with these countries. The EU's efforts to strike deals with countries like Turkey, which is now the main departure point for refugees and other migrants crossing to Europe, have also been met with criticism. Critics argue that the EU is willing to compromise its values by cooperating with countries with poor human rights

I was able to get a preorder in for the fallout 4 pipboy edition for the xbox one this week at target.com.
I was so excited and pumped for it!
I just had a question about when they charge my account (when the preorder ships or when i preordered it), so i sent the contact support page a question about my preorder.
They somehow interpreted it from "when do you charge my card on my account for the preorder" to "cancel my order".
I got the email notification about their huge mistake and i called target as soon as i saw the email.
I told them it was a huge mistake and that i just had a question.
They saw my question and were confused how the person misinterpreted it as a cancel.
They couldn't do anything except give me a 25 dollar card that i did not want!
I wanted the pipboy edition that they screwed up and cancelled!
I am so mad and bummed.
summary: The document discusses a preorder for the Fallout 4 pipboy edition on Xbox One at Target.com. The person is excited about the preorder and sends a question about when the payment will be charged. Target misinterprets the question as a request to cancel the order and sends a notification. The person calls Target and explains the mistake, but all they can offer is a 25 dollar card. The person is unhappy with the outcome.

title: XSUM-36628767:geminipro-ul2
source:
Tributes were paid to service personnel at hundreds of events around the uk on armed forces day.
Earlier prime minister david cameron attended the main celebration at cleethorpes in north east lincolnshire.
It featured an aerobatic display by the red arrows, a battle of britain memorial flight and parachute display by the royal navy, army and raf.
On monday, a flag-raising ceremony was held at city hall, in london, to mark this year's events.
Follow live updates of armed forces day events alex baxter, armed forces champion for north east lincolnshire, said: "hosting armed forces day will give our residents and others in the region an unparalleled opportunity to show their support and appreciation for serving and former armed forces personnel."
The main celebration also included a display of military vehicles, including the sandown-class mine countermeasures vessel hms blyth, the as90 artillery tank and the warrior and terrier armoured vehicles.
North east lincolnshire council leader ray oxby said: "our local armed forces day has previously attracted more than 60,000 people into the area for the weekend to recognise our past and serving military personnel, and i've no doubt that figure will be dwarfed by hosting the national day."
summary: Tributes were paid to service personnel at multiple events in the UK on Armed Forces Day. The main celebration occurred in Cleethorpes, which included a range of displays. A flag-raising ceremony was held in London. Local officials expressed their excitement for the event, expecting a significant attendance.

summary: took shots with friends, brother wanted to show off his new car, but accidentally drank chew spit instead of soda. Vomited on neighbor's yard.

A trailer was taken from burton's foods ltd on ty coch way, cwmbran, torfaen on 17 june.

A hearing at newport magistrates' court heard a third man will appear in court in relation to the alleged theft on friday.
summary: Two men, hailing from Liverpool and Cheshire, were accused of stealing £20,000 worth of biscuits from Burton's Foods Ltd, the company behind popular treats like Jammie Dodgers and Wagon Wheels. title: XSUM-31763768:gpt4-ul2
source:
Bestival has revealed an all-female line-up in its second wave of announcements for this year's isle of wight event.
Charli xcx, ella eyre and lianne la havas will appear alongside the chemical brothers and underworld.
Other festivals have been criticised for the lack of women on their bills.
Last week, music blog crack in the road posted images of edited posters removing all the names of male performers.
The rather blank-looking page was shared on social media, with the bills at reading and leeds, download and t in the park also a focus for criticism.
Neneh cherry, andreya triana and radio 1 dj b.traits are among other female acts to be announced by bestival.
Organiser rob da bank said: "there are shed-loads of amazing people making some startlingly good music at the moment and look, lots of them are female."
This year's bestival theme is summer of love.
It takes place at robin hill country park on the isle of wight between 10 and 13 september, with 25 stages on offer.
Follow @bbcnewsbeat on twitter and radio1newsbeat on youtube
summary: Bestival, to be held on the Isle of Wight, has announced an all-female line-up for its second wave of acts. This decision comes in the light of criticism faced by other festivals for their lack of female performers. Among the acts announced are Charli XCX, Ella Eyre and Lianne La Havas who will share the stage with the Chemical Brothers and Underworld. Neneh Cherry, Andreya Triana, and Radio 1 DJ B.Traits are also included in the line-up. Festival organiser Rob da Bank expressed his excitement about the "shed-loads of amazing people making some startlingly good music at the moment".

title: XSUM-39387550:gpt4-ul2
source:
Us president donald trump has withdrawn his healthcare bill after it failed to gain enough support to pass in congress.
House speaker paul ryan said he and mr trump agreed to pull the vote, after it became apparent it would not get the minimum of 215 republican votes needed.
The last minute move was seen as a huge blow to mr trump.
Repealing and replacing the programme known as obamacare was one of his major election pledges.
Earlier on friday, white house press secretary sean spicer said that the vote would go ahead at 15:30 (19:30 gmt).
Mr trump had reportedly warned republicans that if they did not vote for his bill then they would be stuck with barack obama's healthcare programme for good.
However, multiple reports suggested that between 28 and 35 republicans were opposed to his draft american health care act.
The vote was withdrawn shortly after 15:30, and the house is now in recess.
Republicans currently have a majority in both the house and the senate.
However, some republicans were unhappy that the bill cut health coverage too severely, while others felt the changes did not go far enough.
The bill also appeared unpopular with the public - in one recent poll, just 17% approved of it.
Speaking after the withdrawal, mr trump blamed the democrats for not supporting the bill and predicted that obamacare would "explode".
He said the republicans would probably focus on tax reform for now.
"we have to let obamacare go its own way for a little while," he said, adding that if the democrats were "civilised and came together" the two parties could work out a "great healthcare bill".
How bad was friday's defeat of the american health care act in the house of representatives?
Bad.
Very bad.
The american health care act was the first major piece of legislation pushed by the white house and the republican-controlled congress, a key political test early in the president's term, when he should be at the height of his power and party cohesion at its strongest.
In spite of all of this, mr trump, house speaker paul ryan and the republicans running washington could not get the job done.
For republicans friday wasn't just bad.
It was a disaster.
Read more analysis here.
Earlier, mr ryan told reporters: "we are going to be living with obamacare for the foreseeable future.
"i will not sugar coat this.
This is a disappointing day for us.
Doing big things is hard."
"we were a 10-year opposition party where being against things was easy to do," he said, adding that it was difficult to get "people to agree with each other in how we do things".
Meanwhile, democrat and house minority leader nancy pelosi described it as "a victory for the american people".
And house minority whip steny hoyer said it was a "good day" for americans, adding "we worked over years to assure that the american public would have access to affordable, quality healthcare".
summary: US President Donald Trump has withdrawn his healthcare bill after failing to receive enough support for it to pass in Congress. The failure to repeal and replace Obamacare is viewed as a significant blow to the president as it was a key election pledge. It's estimated between 28-35 Republicans opposed Trump's proposed American Health Care Act, which was largely seen as unpopular with the public due to its severe cuts to health coverage. Despite holding the majority in both the House and Senate, the Republicans were not able to secure the 215 votes needed to pass the bill. Trump has blamed the Democrats for the bill's failure and has suggested he will now shift focus to tax reform policies.

spans.text: due to its severe cuts to health coverage

title: REDDIT-31:gpt4-ul2
source:
Today i made a $4,000 fuck up.
My "mnt req" light had been on in my truck for a month now and i decided i would finally do something about it.
So i drove down to autozone and bought myself an oil change kit (5 qrts oil, oil filter, oil pan, shop towels, funnel, hand cleaner) and an air filter for about $80 total.
I enlisted the help of my step father for his experience and crawled under my truck.
I pointed to a square box under my truck and asked, "is this the one?"
A hearty, "yes!"
Comes from my side and i unscrew the bolt and watch the dark liquid steadily flow into the oil pan beneath it.
I let the liquid drain and crawl out from under my truck.
My step father says to turn the engine on for a second to get the remaining oil out if the engine.
I follow his experienced orders and turn the engine on for a second and turn it off.
The box dripped the last of its drops and i plugged it up.
We screw in the new oil filter and dump in the oil and i turn the key.
The engine comes to life, but idles very low.
My step father checks the dipstick and notes that the oil is very high on the stick and i should let the engine cool off for an accurate reading.
Thinking that i just finished my first successful oil change, i drive to my apartment and head in for the night.
The next morning i woke up and got ready for work.
I opened up the hood of my truck and checked the dipstick.
The oil still showed high, several inches above the "too much" notch.
I replaced the dipstick and closed my hood.
I decided i should probably go to my parent's house and let out some more oil before i go to work, shouldn't be a few minutes for a quart or two, right?
I pull out of my parking space, noticing that reverse took a few seconds to catch before lurching backwards.
I put it in drive and once again i drift in neutral before the gear catches, jumping the truck forward and moving along.
I turn out of the gate and onto the main road when i think some rpm's would maybe fix the problem.
I push the gas and my engine revs up to 5,000 rpm  for a moment before catching first gear.
I drive for about a quarter of a mile at 15 mph before it solidifies that something very serious is wrong with my beloved truck.
I pull off onto a residential street, barely making a protected left turn at my speed.
Once parked, i call my step dad and explain the situation.
He agrees it sounds strange and thinks maybe there is not enough engine oil in the engine.
He drives to me with some of the materials, but after a few minutes we realize we had better let the professionals deal with it.
I call up our local shop and explain the situation.
His tone is ice cold, "do not turn your engine back on.
You drained all of your transmission fluid.
I'm surprised you got as far as you did (6 miles total.)
There could be possible internal damage in your engine from pushing double the oil through it causing dangerously high pressure.
Tow your truck here and we'll handle the rest."
$4,000 and a new transmission later, here i am making this post.
Luckily the engine wasn't damaged.
**edit:** i understand i made a mistake by not doing my own research, but is it really that hard to believe i would trust my own step father to know what he was doing and follow his orders?
Obviously now i know not to trust him, even my mother told me not to trust him anymore after the whole incident.
I don't need you people telling me i fucked up and that i shouldn't have listened to my step dad.
This fuck up and lesson happened before i made this post, not during.
I didn't receive your comments while i was doing the oil change.
I know i fucked up, i know what i did wrong, and i know what **not** to do next time.
summary: The narrator attempted to change the oil in their truck under the guidance of their stepfather. However, a mistake led them to drain the transmission fluid instead of the engine oil. They then proceeded to put additional oil in the truck, mistakenly assuming the oil change had been successful. The following day, they noticed problems with the truck while driving and contacted their stepfather, who suggested that the problem might be caused by insufficient engine oil. They called a local mechanic who informed them that they had mistakenly drained the transmission fluid and filled the engine with too much oil, which may have caused internal engine damage. The damage resulted in the need for a new transmission and cost $4,000. Fortunately, there was no damage to the engine.

title: XSUM-40480356:llama70b-ul2
source:
League two side crewe alexandra have signed defender eddie nolan on a one-year-contract, with the option of a further year based on appearances.
The 28-year-old was a free agent after leaving blackpool, where he played 10 times last season as the tangerines were promoted to league one.
The ex-blackburn and preston man made the majority of his career appearances at scunthorpe, featuring 137 times.
Nolan has become crewe's fourth signing of the summer.
Jordan bowery, michael raynes and chris porter have all moved to david artell's side this summer.
Find all the latest football transfers on our dedicated page.
summary: Crewe Alexandra have signed defender Eddie Nolan on a one-year contract, with the option to extend for another year based on appearances. The 28-year-old had played for Blackburn, Preston, and Scunthorpe previously, and has become the club's fourth signing of the summer.

title: XSUM-38021627:llama7b-ul2
source:
In the scottish football association's statement of thursday evening, there is no mention of money and the kind of cash it would have taken to bring to an end the reign of gordon strachan as national team manager.
That's hardly a surprise.
These things are never made public.
Removing strachan and his coaches and finding replacements would have meant a serious hit to the coffers of an association that has routinely failed to benefit from the millions of euros on offer to those nations who qualify for major championships.
Money was not brought up in the statement, but it's inconceivable that it didn't play a part in the discussion.
Why pay when the world cup campaign is already on life support?
Why not accept your fate of another doomed mission, let him see out of his deal, save the cash and make a change if one needs to be made when the group fixtures are completed?
The sfa couldn't say any of this.
It couldn't say it was unwilling, or unable, to pay off the manager, so a different narrative was delivered in its statement, a narrative of "jam tomorrow".
In this optimistic view of the world, all that was missing was a complimentary pair of pom-poms.
All hope of a play-off spot for the world cup is not lost, they say.
They're clinging to the belief that scotland can garner enough points from a remaining available total of 18 to force their way into the reckoning when the evidence of everybody's eyes tell us otherwise.
Presenting a scenario of scotland reeling off win after win required a fair amount of chutzpah for an association that has watched its team concede seven goals in three winless games.
And that on top of two years without a competitive win against anybody other than malta and gibraltar.
Stewart regan, the sfa's chief executive, is quoted on how adamant strachan is about his team's capacity to make up ground in the group.
How?
He doesn't say.
Regan points out that the board is convinced that strachan still has the "hunger for the challenge".
Hunger shouldn't have anything to do with it when you've failed to qualify for the most easily accessible euros in history and then sit fifth out of six in a world cup qualification group with your dreams going up in a puff of smoke.
Scotland will limp on now until march, when they host slovenia at hampden.
Will we hear again that slovenia is not a must-win?
Will we see anything different?
Will any new players be considered?
Will there be any thoughts about a new formation?
Is there likely to be any acknowledgement that, if scotland keep doing the same things, they are going to end up with the same results?
There was no hint of that in strachan's words in the sfa statement on thursday.
No acceptance that, if he's staying on, he needs to have a major think about what he is doing, who's he selecting and not selecting.
If he had spoken about a new beginning then you might - might - be inclined to buy into it.
Is he even thinking about it that way?
You would hope so, but it's unlikely.
There is so much to ponder.
Does scotland have to follow a slavish adherence to 4-2-3-1?
Can a solution be found to the absence of dominant centre-backs by converting a full-back or a midfielder?
Maybe not, but where are the ideas?
We saw a snapshot of strachan's out-of-the-box thinking when he played ikechi anya at right-back at wembley.
What happens when kieran tierney and andrew robertson are both fit at left-back, along with lee wallace and stephen kingsley?
Is it really one from four there?
Does it have to be that way?
Where's the innovation, the sense of a manager trying something a bit different?
And what about an enhanced cast of characters on the scene?
Aberdeen's graeme shinnie, fulham's tom cairney, brighton's jamie murphy, aston villa's ross mccormack, stoke city's phil bardsley and, yes, if he ever starts playing and scoring again, middlesbrough's jordan rhodes.
There are others, either on the periphery of the squad or totally divorced from it, that could be looked at properly.
Too often, strachan has been rigid in his thinking and it's done nothing for the team.
The tired mantra that "the players are just not there" is an entirely bogus argument when all that is being asked is that scotland become truly competitive, like northern ireland.
They have decent premier league centre-halves - from west brom, who sit 11th - and an impressive midfielder from southampton - who are 10th - but who have precious little else in terms of quality and, most especially, depth.
And yet, from a squad largely made up of championship, league one and scottish premiership players, northern ireland get the kind of results that are beyond scotland.
The attitude of "no manager could do better with these players" is fatalism.
It's tantamount to a white flag being raised.
A quitter's charter, the central tenet of which is blown to the high heavens by what michael o'neill is doing with his meagre resources in belfast.
The sfa's statement on thursday did nothing to challenge the view that a blind faith - or a meek acceptance of failure -  has taken an ever firmer hold of hampden.
When they can't get a draw against georgia, can't beat lithuania and can't avoid a drubbing against a moderate team like slovakia, the idea of scotland suddenly morphing into a points machine is a hard sell.
Scotland took the most affordable option, but a dwindling number of supporters would agree that it was the best one.
summary: The Scottish Football Association (SFA) has announced that Gordon Strachan will remain as the national team manager, despite calls for his departure following a string of poor performances. The SFA statement did not mention any financial considerations, but it is widely acknowledged that removing Strachan and his coaching staff would have been a costly endeavor. The SFA is optimistic that Scotland can still qualify for the World Cup, despite being in fifth place in their qualification group with only three matches remaining. The statement did not provide any concrete plans for improving the team, other than Strachan's desire to continue to work with the players.

spans.text: continue to work with the players

title: XSUM-12889429:falcon7b-ul2
source:
Mining giant rio tinto has lowered its minimum acceptances target slightly in a last ditch effort to takeover south africa's riversdale mining.
Rio's offer of 16.50 australian dollars ($16.42; â£10.14) is now conditional on 47% of shareholders accepting it by 6 april.
Previously its minimum target was 50%.
The move came after talks on the a$3.9bn offer between rio and riversdale major shareholder, brazil's csn.
If it fails to reach the new threshold, rio tinto will pay riversdale shareholders only a$16 a share.
So far only 41% have said yes.
The other key shareholder in riversdale is tata steel of india, which recently increased its stake to 27% and also has a director on the company's board.
Csn, brazil's largest steelmaker, has also increased its riversdale stake to 19.9%.
summary: Rio Tinto has reduced its minimum acceptance target for Riversdale Mining to 47% to avoid a failed A$3.9bn offer.

The doctor diagnoses the patient with a diabetic foot ulcer and orders an ankle brachial index to determine the blood supply to the foot. The doctor does not prescribe any additional antibiotics at this time and recommends follow-up appointments to monitor progress.
